Introduction to ggplot

Author

ag@hvl.no

Load packages

  • We start by loading some packages

. . .

library(ggplot2)
library(tinytex)
library(tidyverse)

library(ggpubr)

Empty plot

ggplot(data = mtcars)

Data and mapping

ggplot(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg))

mapping in geom_point

gg1 <-   ggplot(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg)) +
  geom_point()

gg2 <-   ggplot(data = mtcars) +
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg))

ggarrange(gg1, gg2, labels = c("mapping = aes in ggplot", "mapping = aes in geom_*"),
          nrow = 1)

ggplot(data, mapping, …) and geom_point(mapping, data, …)

ggplot() +
  #geom_point has mapping as first argument. We have to use named arguments
  #or switch their order
  geom_point(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg))

What happens if we use both?

## combine aes
gg3 <-   ggplot(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(x = disp, colour = factor(cyl))) +
##  geom_point(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(y = mpg), col = 'blue')
  geom_point(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(y = mpg))
#inherit.aes    = FALSE, overrides the default aesthetics, rather than combining with them.
gg4 <-   ggplot(data =  mtcars, mapping = aes(x = disp, colour = factor(cyl))) +
##  geom_point(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(y = mpg), col = 'blue')
  geom_point(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(x = qsec, y = mpg), show.legend = TRUE, inherit.aes = FALSE)
## x = disp removed from ggplot
gg5 <-   ggplot(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(colour = factor(cyl))) +
##  geom_point(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(y = mpg), col = 'blue')
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = qsec, y = mpg), show.legend = TRUE, inherit.aes = FALSE)

ggarrange(gg3, gg4, gg5, labels = c("inherit.aes = TRUE\n(default)", "inherit.aes = FALSE", "no x = disp\nin ggplot"),
          nrow = 1)

Playing with aes()

ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = mtcars, mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg, colour = factor(cyl), size = qsec))

Playing with aes()

ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = mtcars,
             mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg, colour = factor(cyl), alpha = 3.6*(0.25*1609.347)/qsec,
                           shape = factor(ifelse(am, "Man", "Aut"))), size=4) +
  labs(colour = "cyl", alpha = "speed\n(km/h)", shape = "trans-\nmission")

Exercise:

Examine if one of the available aesthetics might do a better job at showing differences in speed.

Exercise:

How do you think the plot below is made?

Adding a geom_smooth() layer

ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data = mtcars,
    mapping = aes(
      x = disp,
      y = mpg, 
      colour = factor(cyl), 
      size = 3.6*(0.25*1609.347)/qsec, 
      shape = factor(
        # Note codeing am
        # 0 automatic, 1 manual
        ifelse(
          am, 
          "Aut", 
          "Man"
          )
        )
      )
    ) +
  labs(
    colour = "cyl", 
    size = "speed\n(km/h)", 
    shape = "trans-\nmission"
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    data = mtcars, 
    mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg)
    )
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'

Exercise:

Which parameter control the smoothness? Plot again with “half the smoothness”.

Exercise:

Change the confidence interval from 95% to 99%. Will it become narrower or broader? Then draw both the 95% and 99% confidence interval. How can we distinguish them?

Linear model, lm

Practice exercise: How can we get ggplot2 to draw the regression line? (hint! see help for geom_smooth()). Generate the new plot (concentrate on the plain points and the regression line).

Linear model, rlm

ggplot(
  data = mtcars, 
  mapping = aes(
    x = disp, 
    y = mpg
    )
  ) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE
    ) +
  # robust lm
  geom_smooth(
    method = MASS::rlm, 
    colour = 'Red', 
    se = FALSE
    )

Other data in the plot

# A tibble: 3 × 3
    cyl m_mpg m_disp
  <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>
1     4  26.7   105.
2     6  19.7   183.
3     8  15.1   353.
## create tibble from scratch
df_mean <-   tibble(
  cyl = c("avg. car 4 cyl.", "avg. car 6 cyl.", "avg. car 8 cyl."), 
  mpg = c(22.66, 17.74, 15.10), 
  disp = c(105.14, 183.31, 353.10)
  )
df_mean
# A tibble: 3 × 3
  cyl               mpg  disp
  <chr>           <dbl> <dbl>
1 avg. car 4 cyl.  22.7  105.
2 avg. car 6 cyl.  17.7  183.
3 avg. car 8 cyl.  15.1  353.

Exercise:

The first column involved some typing. How can we reduce the required typing? (hint! see paste() and seq())

df_mean
# A tibble: 3 × 3
  cyl               mpg  disp
  <chr>           <dbl> <dbl>
1 avg. car 4 cyl.  22.7  105.
2 avg. car 6 cyl.  17.7  183.
3 avg. car 8 cyl.  15.1  353.

Two different datasets

ggplot(
  data = mtcars, 
  mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    mapping = aes(colour = factor(cyl))
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = MASS::rlm, 
    colour = 'Red', 
    se = FALSE
    ) +
  geom_point(
    data = df_mean, 
    mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg), 
    colour = "black", 
    size = 3
    ) +
  geom_text(
    data = df_mean, 
    mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg, label = cyl), 
    colour = "black", 
    vjust = 1.5
    )
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
  • Note data = df_mean in last geom_point() in the code.

Two different datasets cont.

p_common <- ggplot(
  data = mtcars, 
  mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    aes(colour = factor(cyl))
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = MASS::rlm, 
    colour = 'Red', 
    se = FALSE
    ) +
  geom_point(
    data = df_mean, 
    mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg), 
    colour = "black", 
    size = 3
    ) +
  labs(colour = "cyl") +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")
# update a ggplot object

# add text labels by geom_text
p1 <- p_common +  
  geom_text(
    data = df_mean, 
    mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg, label = cyl),
    colour = "black", 
    vjust = 1.5, 
    hjust = 0.2
    )
# add text labels by geom_label
p2 <-   p_common +  
  geom_label(
    data = df_mean, 
    mapping = aes(x = disp, y = mpg, label = cyl), 
    colour = "black", 
    vjust = 1.5, 
    hjust = 0.2, 
    alpha = 0.25
    ) +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom") +  
  labs(colour = "cyl")

Plot two ggplot objects p1 and p2

# ggpubr makes it easy to place 
# two objects side by side
ggarrange(
  p1, 
  p2, 
  ncol = 2, 
  nrow = 1, 
  labels = c(
    "geom_text()",
    "geom_label()"
    )
  )

Plot two ggplot objects p1 and p2 cont.

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

Three variables

  • pseudo 3-d plot (not to usefull)
  • 2-d + aesthetics

Three variables cont.

cp1 <-   ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data = mtcars, 
    mapping = aes(
      x = hp, 
      y = wt,
      colour = 1609.347/(2*qsec^2)
      ),
    size = 4) +
  geom_text(
    data = mtcars, 
    mapping = aes(x = hp, y = wt, label = rownames(mtcars)),
    colour = "black", 
    size = 2, 
    hjust = 0.7, 
    vjust = 3
    ) +
  labs(
    size = "Average\nacceleration", 
    colour = "Average\nacceleration"
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    data = mtcars, 
    mapping = aes(x = hp, y = wt), 
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE
    ) +
  theme_classic()
#  scale_size_continuous(range = c(3, 12), 
#  breaks = seq(1, 5, by=0.25)) +
Ignoring unknown labels:
• size : "Average acceleration"
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

Three variables cont.

bp1 <- ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data = mtcars, 
    mapping = aes(x = hp, y = wt, size = 1609.347/(2*qsec^2)), 
    colour = "blue", 
    alpha = 0.25
    ) +
  geom_text(
    data = mtcars, 
    mapping = aes(x = hp, y = wt, label = rownames(mtcars)),
    colour = "black", 
    size = 2, 
    hjust = 0.5, 
    vjust = 3
    ) +
  labs(size = "Average\nacceleration") +
  scale_size_continuous(
    range = c(1, 10),
    breaks = seq(1, 5, by = 0.25)
    ) +
  theme_classic()

Another strategy; facets

ggplot(
  data = mtcars, 
  mapping = aes(
    x = hp, 
    y = 1609.347/(2*qsec^2)
    )
  ) +
  facet_wrap(~cut_number(wt, n =3)) +
  geom_point(
    aes(colour = cut_number(
      wt, 
      n = 3)
      )
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE
    )
`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

Facets, whole dataset in background

#new dataframe to use for the grey points
hp_acc <- data.frame(
  hp = mtcars$hp, 
  acc = 1609.347/(2*mtcars$qsec^2)
  )

ggplot(
  data = mtcars, 
  mapping = aes(x = hp, y = 1609.347/(2*qsec^2))
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = hp_acc, 
    mapping = aes(x = hp, y = acc), colour = "grey80"
    ) +
  facet_wrap(
    ~cut_number(
      wt, 
      n =3 , 
      labels = c("Light", "Medium", "Heavy")
      )
    ) +
  geom_point(
    mapping = aes(colour = cut_number(
      wt, 
      n = 3, 
      labels = c("Light", "Medium", "Heavy")
      )
      ),
    show.legend = FALSE
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE
    ) +
  labs(
    y = "Mean acceleration (m/s^2)", 
    colour = "Weight"
    )

Facets, whole dataset in background

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

Click here to experiment with the plot.

Two facet variables

ggplot(
  data = mtcars, 
  mapping = aes(x = hp, y = 1609.347/(2*qsec^2))
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = hp_acc, 
    mapping = aes(x = hp, y = acc), 
    colour = "grey80"
    ) +
  facet_grid(
    factor(cyl)~cut_number(
      wt, 
      n =3 , 
      labels = c("Light", "Medium", "Heavy"))
    ) +
  geom_point(
    mapping = aes(
      colour = cut_number(
        wt, 
        n = 3, 
        labels = c("Light", "Medium", "Heavy")
        )
      ),
    show.legend = FALSE
    ) +
  geom_smooth(
    method = "lm", 
    se = FALSE
    ) +
  labs(
    y = "Mean acceleration", 
    colour = "Weight"
    )

Two facet variables

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

Other graphical systems in R

  • Classic (plot())
  • Lattice package
  • many more

Lattice

library(lattice)
histogram(
  x = ~mpg | factor(cyl),  
  type = "density", 
  data = mtcars
  )

Classic

#save old par values
old.par <-   par(no.readonly = TRUE)
#set par
layout(
  matrix(
    c(1,2,3), 
    nrow = 1, 
    ncol = 3, 
    byrow = TRUE
    )
  )
with(
  subset(
    mtcars, 
    cyl == 4), 
  hist(
    mpg, 
    breaks = c(7, 12, 17, 22, 27, 32, 37), 
    freq = FALSE
    )
  )
with(
  subset(mtcars, cyl == 6), 
  hist(
    mpg, 
    breaks = c(7, 12, 18, 23, 27, 32, 37), 
    freq = FALSE
    )
  )
with(
  subset(
    mtcars, 
    cyl == 8
    ), 
  hist(
    mpg, 
    breaks = c(9, 14, 19, 24, 27, 32, 37), 
    freq = FALSE
    )
  )

Classic cont.

# reset pat to old values
par(old.par)
